content.body: yeah, I gathered :)
often the things they want to do aren't at all useful
like creating associations between things that are right next to each other
careful, you might lose your accessibility expert credentials if you keep saying sensible things like that :-)
hixie, lol :P
BenMillard: That's why I keep suggesting that user testing is a stronger argument than theory.
jgraham, indeed
I wonder if I have lost more than I've gained by ignoring Public-HTML for the past several months
I've certainly gained a lot of time, with which I've done many fun and some productive things
BenMillard: It was pretty quiet for a bit. Then about a week or two ago it all kicked off again
Same topics, similar arguments
since it all gets publically archived, I wonder if there's any gain in re-responding
It gets archived but there's so much that nobody's ever going to actually read the archives
so clearly the solution is to keep reposting the better arguments, so that nobody will miss them
BenMillard: I guess the problem is xkcd syndrome http://xkcd.com/386/
Philip`, alternatively, the people who decide HTML5's development probably saw and took on board the better points first time around, so repeating them doesn't change HTML5's direction very much?
jgraham, perfect!
there are three main topics being discussed right now
img alt: i think i missed a couple of key things the first time (how the {} thing affects tool developers)
well, i guess the second time, not the first time
so i don't know what i'll do with that, probably go back to just making alt="" be not given when you have no alt text
table headers: i haven't yet seen a clear description of the problem, but if there is a problem, then we'll have to address it
rdfa: i haven't managed to get ben to actually describe the problem yet
Hixie, could you disambiguate when you talk about "Ben"? a couple of times I've seen you say that and it's put me into a state of panic since I don't remember that happenning :)
if "no alt text" means no precise equivalent, I think that would probably force me into non-conformance since I don't think that yields the best results for end-users.
oh sorry
i mean ben adida in this case

webben: so what text would you suggest for the following cases? a generated image for a fractal explorer; the images in google maps in map view and satellite view; the street view images in google maps; an image uploaded as part of a batch upload with no information; a webcam
Hixie: I'm happier with a text description of those than no alt text.
in all of these cases, the software has no idea what the image is so can't describe it at all
Yes, a text equivalent is better, but I think a text description is better than zilch.
Hixie: alt="fractal" alt="uploaded photo"

Hixie: FWIW my guess is that there is a strong enough use case for people accessing the images out of the main flow that something like "fractal", "map tile", "street view", "photo", "webcam" would be better than nothing
webben: yeah see i don't agree that that is better, i think it's actually worse
but IANAATU
ATU?
AT user?
yes :)
woot
well that's what the {phoot} idea was for
{photo} even
well, i'd prefer being able to demark an alt as non-equivalent with an attribute, but i'd still include it.
My feeling is that in order of worst to best we have nothing, alt={photo}, no-text-equivalent alt="photo"
But I agree that all three suck for different reasons
i just don't see an attribute working for this
it has so many issues
i think the net misuse of a new attribute would make the total level fo accessibility lower
I've seen gallery software use alt="Photo" as a default
forums have "User posted image" or similar
I guess the fourth possibility is no attribute and no special syntax, just require the end user to work out if it is supposed to be a description or a text equivalent
Hixie: does the attribute have any use-cases other than for hypothetical future software?
jgraham, yes, which is hardly much of a challenge in the cases I've seen
Hixie: e.g. do you expect a near-future version of Lynx to treat non-equivalents differently?
or was the idea that {} would force Lynx into treating them differently?
webben: I think in theory AT could only voice "image" if there is @n-t-e or {} and just read the alt text with no delimiter otherwise
can't see why an AT would want to do that.
But in practice misuse of {} or an attribute might make that not work
webben: Want to do what?
'voice "image" if there is @n-t-e or {} '
oh wait i see what you mean
jgraham: Misuse of alt="photo" (regardless of what the spec says) means that in practice AT can't just read the alt text with no delimiter

Philip`: I would expect that to be the case as well. So unless there is something I haven't thought of (likely) it seems just as well to say "sometimes @alt is a replacement, sometimes it is a description, work it out for yourselves"
(with rules like the current ones about when it should be a replacement and when a description)
the idea is that on an ideally written page, an with alt="" can be completely substituted for its alt="" text, with no indication that an image was there
I guess it makes Henri's image checker less useful
but that these s we're talking about would need to indicate that there is an image present
since that's the whole point
so we theoretically need a distinction
lack of alt="", {}, n-t-e, something
Hixie: The problem with designing for an ideally written page is that you're pretty much the only person who writes them :)
isn't persuaded that would be an ideal page.
(although when I read feeds in thunderbird with images disabled, it is immensely irritating when people describe a picture rather than replace it either with "" or an actual equivalent)
webben: For whom? I think part of the issue might be that the text browser case is a bit different from the screenreader case
People like to communicate with images. Therefore being able to retrieve and share and bookmark etc images is an important use-case.
i want to be able to do that with a text browser, I think I'd want to be able to do that if I were a screen reader user too.
Hmm.
you don't want to bookmark most images
you probably don't even notice most images
is going to bed now even though he hasn't managed to put a stop to wrongness on the internet :)
e.g. "RSS" is often an image
never said most images.
sure
i'm just saying that it's an important use case but only for a small subset of images
although being able to grab that icon _is_ useful to people authoring content
jgraham, it's good to break that habit
as in, put your personal wellbeing ahead of timely responses to internet arguments

Hixie: being able to differentiate that subset (@role?) might be useful. but i think that would need to work as an authorial opt-in, since most people probably wouldn't bother and there's a huge body of existing content not making such a differentiation.
the problem with any attribute here is it'd be massively misused
much more so than a special syntax, based on what i've seen of web authoring practices so far
It seems they're all tripping over each other in making @scope seem like a plague...
Hixie: not having to include alt will also be massively "misused".
it already is
i don't think this would make things worse
What's the reasoning for that?
if anything it might be a net benefit since we might reduce the amount of totally bogus alt text, which is arguably worse than no alt text in some cases
is there evidence that totally bogus alt text is a worse overall problem for users than no alt text?
and might that change if the "no alt text" group got higher?
*larger

"I then went on safari. blahblah The elephants were cool, but the tigers were the best: bdasflsjd" is not as good an experience as "I then went on safari. [IMAGE] The elephants were cool, but the tigers were the best: [IMAGE]"
(not that either is especially great, of course)
i'm not talking about the individual experience
i'm talking about which actually constitutes the bigger problem for end-users on the web now.
(I posit that the second one above is also better than "I then went on safari. elephants The elephants were cool, but the tigers were the best: tigers")
I posit "I then went on safari. image elephants The elephants were cool, but the tigers were the best: image tigers " is even better.

(I personally alsos think the [IMAGE] case, where "[IMAGE]" is something the UA shows in a different font/voice/color/whatever, is better than "I then went on safari. photo The elephants were cool, but the tigers were the best: photo")
i don't know of any reasearch into what problems blind users have experienced on the web so far
my own personal attempts at using screen readers have indicated that the screen readers themselves are a far bigger problem than anything the web pages do (based primarily on my experience with JAWS)
well it's not just blind users who suffer from no alt and bogus alt.

text browser users suffer from it a lot too, but there aren't many of us (i use text browsers several times a week and alt="" isn't a big deal for me, though personally I would much rather people omit alt="" than give bogus or repeating alt"")
search engines are also a UA which makes use of alt for the benefit of many users, for example, image searches
i work for a search engine
i assure you alt="" is the least of our worries
though if we were forced to comment on it, we'd much rather have no alt="" at all than have bogus alt=""
repetition isn't such a big deal for us though
since we can just filter out repeated text
also voice recognition users
voice recognition users?
*speech recognition, sorry
you mean for input? or do you mean speech synthesis?
input
i don't understand how alt="" affects input, can you elaborate?
images and icons that are controls mainly
e.g. an image of home, you say "home", the speech recognition looks for a link or button with "home" as a detectable text equivalent
I think in practice they have to make a lot of use of title too; I dunno how they try to handle missing alt and title other than maybe link numbering.
Hixie: here's some actual HTML guidelines from a vendor: http://ct.scansoft.com/customerfiles/kbasefiles/3067/wp_DNS_HTML.pdf in case that's of interest
oh well for images that are controls the spec is clear that alt="" is required
I was going to ask. That's good at least.
that won't change if you make alt non-conforming?
what if you have a div with tabindex and onclick and an img inside it?
the only thing in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/embedded0.html#alt that is likely to change is the tiny subsubsection labeled "Images whose contents are not known"
yeah, problem is it's not easy for a validator to distinguish those from other images.
looks at the file above
oh well images are far from the biggest problem there
i mean, you have to use <h1> only for headers but how is the validator supposed to know?
Hixie: well, yes, it's a general problem with conformance testing. but in terms of trying to ensure control images have alt, it's potentially important
depends how you define control images in such a way that a checker could distinguish the two
i don't think we can
but we have this problem anyway distinguishing decorative elements from other elements
Hixie: can you define a subset of controls that can be checked?
well if you read the link i gave above you'll see one of the first things it does say though is that an image in a link that has no other text must have non-empty alt=""
which is probably all wecan do really
machine-checkability-wise, anyway
dragon's document seems in line with what the spec says today
doesn't really affect the problematic images we were talking about
also button and input type="image" and imagemap?
<input type=image> and <area> are dealt with separately and have separate requirements that basically always require non-empty alt=""
Hixie: I don't think it does affect the problematic images, no.
okay
(well <input> isn't in the spec yet but will be)
button?
what about it?
shouldn't the spec mention button along with link at the above url?
oooh, good call
webben: spec updated
urgh, 521 new mails
what does the "@" mean in "-rw-r--r--@"?
Hixie: ACL I think
any idea how i view the acl info?
ls -e didn't work
Hixie: http://arstechnica.com/reviews/os/macosx-10-4.ars/8
really, -e didn't work?
hrm
that suggests @ does not mean acl
since no @ appears in their listings
indeed
Hixie: I can't remember and Googling gives me the article jacobolus mentioned
maybe it means there's fork data or something
or attributes
I might misremember the meaning of @
Hixie: If the file or directory has extended attributes, the permissions field printed by the -l option is followed by a '@' character.
xattr --list file
so actually the page you want is http://arstechnica.com/reviews/os/macosx-10-4.ars/7 :)
yeah i was just playing with mdls which also seems to list attributes
ok anyway
it is an attributes thing
no, mdls lists info from the spotlight store
which is different from xattrs
are ACLs a special case of attributes?
and it is *very very* frustrating that setting custom xattrs can’t put custom metadata in spotlight :(
hsivonen: yes, ACLs are stored in xattrs
ok. so my memory isn't totally broken
man mac is confusing :-P
hsivonen: I'm not sure you can get to them though through normal xattr APIs
sighs loudly
i wish i had some data to go on with this thing
i really have no idea what to do
which is a pretty ridiculous position to be in given the rarity with which this will affect users
(it's not like blind users surf to flickr often)
why do you have no idea what to do?
I thought it was figured out
with the {}'s etc.
people have raised a valid concern with the {}
which is that it increases the effort of people trying to write accessible content
Hixie: do you have data on how often people with text input difficulties execise their right to speech by publishing photos?
increases the effort?
as in, it's too hard to put {…} in?
because they now have to work around cases where the alt="" might end up containing {} through no fault of their own, e.g. if the alt is user input
what's wrong with {} ?
hsivonen: 100% of my sample of 1 has done it
that seems like a vanishingly unlikely edge case
what naïve user is going to make the whole alt name start w/ { and end w/ }?
jacobolus: yeah but the people who care about accessibility (the group we want to piss off the least) will want to do the right thing in all cases anyway, so it will disproportionately hurt them

tantek: if you give the user a text field for writing alt text, your program needs to do something when the value entered into the field starts with { and ends with }, since just passing that through would leak user input into writing the wrong meaning into the file format
Hixie: so “do the right thing” here will be interpreted as what? strip out the {} if users add them?
jacobolus: or add a space or something
bleh
Hixie: it strikes me that it's still easier to “do the right thing” under the {} system than currently
why would { } be the wrong meaning?
e.g. what if a user types nothing in the box?
what if the img was a picture of some curly braces?
tantek: {...} has special meaning according to html5 right now (will likely change)
jacobolus: like i said, i've no idea what to do
then escape it
& has special meaning hence &
not sure what the big deal is
tantek: right, so escaping means more data munging cases to handle than putting the flag out of band into a separate attribute

tantek: there's no defined escaping mechanism for this right now, but even if there was, the big deal is that we are making life harder for the only group who are doing the right thing, which is staggeringly bad language design
so what's the alternate proposal?
make up a new attribute?
i have 23 alternative proposals on my list right now
they all suck in one way or another
eep
how many with any realistic chances?
what is the URL that documents the need for this { } feature?
tantek: whatwg.com/html5
whatwg.org
erm, org
but the spec doesn't document the need
the use case, the background, the group/people that asked for it etc.
tantek: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2008Aug/0602.html documents some of it
search for {...}
er
actually
similar problem exists today if someone exj�8s < or " or > into user input meant for an alt attribute right?
search for "the tentative decision"
no, we have a defined escaping for that and it is wildly implemented already
I really need to get to the bottom of 4 concurrent validations of up to 1 MB pages exhausting 1 GB of RAM
there has to be some silly data structure growth somewhere
and some crazy markup out there on the Web
jacobolus: http://damowmow.com/temp/alt lists the proposals so far
hsivonen: how is the 1,000,000 validations plan going?
Hixie: I was able to download 93% of the pages successfully. validating them now
Hixie: it seems that either the parser or the validator has a memory leak
ah
(I'm reusing the parser and validator objects)
Hixie: just go for B.1
the dmoz validation run hung for unknown reasons
jacobolus: disallowing flickr is not a workable solution
(joke)
oh many people think B.1 is a good solution
many people are nutgs
Hixie: oh, and real Web content has made a couple of assertions to fire
or nuts even
which is interesting
real web content is insane
also, Japanese Web content exposed a bug in my charset decoder driver code that I hadn't seen with UTF-8 content
Hixie: what would the practical effect be if a website allowed user input and the user put in “{picture of grandma on her 80th birthday}” or whatever?
i.e. what would a screen reader do with that content
well that would actually be correct alternative text for that image
it would cause the UA to attract attention to the fact that there is an image with the caption "picture of..."
that is, if the {} proposal goes through
how is {foo} treated differently from foo
right that 's what i was assuming
{foo} causes the UA to attract attention to the fact that there is an image
foo causes the UA to say "foo" without mentioning the image
I see
that seems like pretty minimal harm then from the vanishingly unlikely false positives
Hixie, that doesn't match what existing screen readers doo with the "foo" case. They do say "image: foo"
JohnResig: yt?
existing screen readers fail long before they get around to rendering any html
jacobolus: i agree
jacobolus: won't stop the people who care from being even more careful though
I mean, {} aren’t even meaningful characters in english

FWIW - as someone who prefers not to see new syntax, capturing such an annotation in another attribute seems preferable to overloading *both* an existing attribute and the use of characters which could mean something themselves.
sure, but in the "foo" case, why should they stop notifying the user that there's an image there?
maybe someone will accidentally put them in a description of a mathematical formula or something
tantek: another attribute doesn't work because the abuse such an attribute would get would almost certainly cause more damage than the little benefit it would cause
tantek: we've already seen that authors are completely incapable of reliably making use of attributes like alt="" or longdesc=""
tantek: and this would be an even more subtle attribute
Lachy: the whole point of alt="" is that it is replacement text that removes mention of the image
virtuelv: isn't it 4 AM in EDT?
jacobolus: probably
I'll have to catch up when I get to Turin this afternoon then
jacobolus: the original complaint re alt={} was latex, fwiw, which could quite legitimately end up with {}
I'm a bit puzzled about one thing he's doing with Sizzle
how does it legitimately end w/ {} ??
i mean {somethingsomething}
Hixie: you just mean that's what latex → html converters do currently?
yes
probably one particular latex → html converter, which could be trivially changed

Hixie, your point that the cognitive/incentive barrier to usage of such an attribute makes it useless is a good one, and justifies not only not introducing such an effectively useless attribute, but any such equivalent mechanism, *especially* one that introduces additional syntax.
tantek: agreed
tantek: so that suggests making alt="" optional for this case, but then we have no way to orient speech synthesis users when they navigate image-by-image
the lack of a mechanism does not rationally justify introducing an ineffective mechanism
tantek: agreed

tantek: however the aforementioned case is important enough to certain authors that at least one has said they will always include some alternative text, even if it is not suitable for linear navigation (i.e. reading the page straight through)
do they do so now on existing pages?
those do yeah
it makes those pages harder to read if you have images disabled though, e.g. in a text browser
which is bad
and so not really what we want to require
those authors have *way* fewer photos in their photostream than tantek
yup
below what author/content/sample size threshold do you reach the point of diminishing returns of language design improvements/features?
tantek: oh we're way below that already
tantek: but i still have to say _something_
Hixie: it seems to me, though, that part of the problem is that you want the result to make sense in Lynx instead of sacrificing Lynx and focusing solely on the AT case
as a regular lynx user, i don't think it's unreasonable to have things make sense in lynx
it's also a matter of it making sense in graphical browsers with images disabled
Hixie: that means you are letting non-accessibility issues get in the way of accessibility issues
this isn't an accessibility issue
it's an html issue
right :-)
however, the accessibility alt-need conditions aren't curable. the need to turn off images in a graphical browser is curable (by flat-rate 3G/EDGE mobile subscriptions)
yeah well it might be curable in theory, but many parts of africa aren't getting 3G in the next ten years
and hell, many parts of america don't have decent EDGE
another case for alt text being readable is the very common occurrence of web based mail interfaces (e.g. Gmail) presenting HTML email with image loading disabled for security/privacy reasons.
hsivonen: and frankly, it's only a problem for AT users when they navigate image-by-image
Hixie: the experts say that's the usual mode of operation
hsivonen: sure, so we have to handle it
Hixie: after all, VO, for one, doesn't even have sane UI for reading content in a continuous manner
hsivonen, the usual mode of operation of web based email interfaces is image loading disabled.
anyway
(I'd use VO for non-accessibility things if it had a "read on from here" command)
no. idead. what. to. do.
hsivonen: just select a bunch of text and use the speech service
thus the Lynx / graphical browsers with images disabled case is far more common than those two specific use cases might imply
doesn't really matter how common all these cases are, they're all common enough that we have to deal with them
it seems to me that the headers/id discussion and the RDFa discussion revolve around a similar issue (except headers/id has more UA legacy than RDFa)
they certainly have in common that i don't understand the problems they are trying to solve

that is, if we consider something like "simple things should be easy and complex things should be possible", there's one faction that is willing to make simple cases less easy in order to support complex cases with the same model and another faction that mainly cares about making simple case easy and is willing to cut support for some complex cases
hsivonen, turning images off is also common in e.g. Russia
as bandwidth is ridiculously expensive there still

Hixie: I *think* I understand the problems RDFa is supposed to solve. In the case of ccREL, I just think that some of the problems are non-problem and some problem won't be successfully solved by the proposed solution
Hixie: also, I don't think that the generic problem RDFa solves is a problem whose solutions yield good markup
hsivonen: i'm hoping ben adida can actually explain the problem
i can come up with problems that i think maybe they are solving
I think RDFa proponents aren't doing their cause any favors when their conference slides take well-known microformats and then show how it can by done "right" with RDFa
and the RDFa version is always more verbose
i.e. crufty
yeah, that's funny
can anyone find the link to joshue's usability videos?
crufty, more verbose markup examples are nearly always promoted by those who don't actually write markup (publish content on the web) for a living, nor talk with those who do so on a daily basis.
i searched youtube but can't figure out the right terms
i know they're on youtube somewhere
does "HTML5 WG header/id test" help?
it should anyway, http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=HTML5+WG+header%2Fid+test
also, I have non-techincal reasons why I don't like some aspects of ccREL
the "extensibility" afforded by "requires"/"permits" is effectively catering for license proliferation
yeah i'm not a big fan of CC's work to be honest
and in the public licensing space, CC is responsible for more license proliferation than any other single organization
they made some interesting licenses, but then they kept on doing things and i'm not sure i like it
yeah
Hixie: I like CC-by, CC-by-sa and perhaps CC-by-nc-nd
notes he works for a group that has done a lot of work to reduce license proliferation in software
hsivonen: which is nd again?
I like the cc-pd and CC0 work
annevk: yes, thanks
annevk: perfect

tantek: thanks

a few more Jeremy has created here: http://adactio.com/extras/schedules/
man i wish i could find some video of blind users just browsing the web
tantek: it really sucks if authors need to take steps like that to make stuff work with the current state of AT
actually, the use of headers and id in those examples is not for AT (not directly anyway) but rather to better markup the data in an extractable way with minimal duplication of data
it turned out that headers/id was designed well enough for this use
and incidentally, AT benefits result

hsivonen, indeed (to your previous remarks re ccRel). note there are also incrementally advanced license microformat efforts underway: http://microformats.org/wiki/licensing
tantek: interesting to see that the microformats community is on the case.
tantek: Ben Adida on the WHATWG list said the microformats folks turned them down
slowly and steadily, but there have been more and more folks interested in incrementally taking steps beyond rel-license, but much more practical than ccRel/RDFa
tantek: did you just turn down some of the more theoretical parts of ccREL?
microformats folks turned down assumptions that namespaces are necessary etc.
and asked for research to be done on content/license use in the wild on the web to document use cases
theoretical proposals are rejected as a matter of course in the microformats community
heh

ok

how about this

we just say that if an image has no alt text, then it must have at least one of the following, and the first of the following that it has must have enough information about hte image to help orient the user if he is navigating by image (and have the ATs read out the relevant information):
- title="" attribute on the itself
- of the
- heading of the section that contains the
notes that he suggested something like that a long time ago

Hixie: Existing software isn't going to make any use of legend or heading, but requiring title where alt is absent _might_ be a viable approach (in backwards compatibility terms). One would need to check exactly what existing software does.
except for the heading of the section one
e.g. I think some screen readers will read title where there is no alt.
I don't know if, when you disable images in your browser, you see title if there is no alt though.
just saying "image" is good enough for legacy handling
i mean it's not what we want long term
but we shouldn't constrain ourselves to only what today's ATs do
especially given how horrifically bad today's ATs are
Is saying "image" what they all do.
again maintains today's AT is little worse than today's other UAs, but they're both what the spec needs to work iwth.
in the case of JAWS, there's about 212 configuration options that control what it does

I don't like allowing alt to be omitted just when the section has a heading because there's no way to distinguish between when the image is the primary content of the section, or if it's just a minor part of a larger section
ATs today are far, far worse usability wise than today's browsers
i mean there's not even a comparison
I know that's your opinion. I just don't think the differences are as radical as you do.
it's like comparing the usability of CP/M with the usability of Mac OS X
I also don't think it matters, just like it doesn't really matter how bad I think IE is.
it still needs to be taken into account
Lachy: if it's a minor part, then it can't have alt omitted anyway. you can only omit it for key content.
webben: like i said, i think saying "image" is good enough
webben: saying the title is even better
Hixie, no, that's not what I meant.
Lachy: do you have a page that shows an example of an img where alt="" could legitimately be omitted without the section header being useful?
and where it would have neither title="" nor <figure>?
Hixie, no. You seem to have misunderstood me.
possibly :-)
there are 2 cases that I think need to be distinguished:
Hixie: Could one require describedby attributes explicitly linking the image to the heading?
1. The flickr case where there's an image and the section heading relates directly to that image, much like a caption.
webben: wouldn't that be redundant?
Hixie: You mean if the image was the sole content of the section?
In that case, alt could be omitted according to the rule "heading of the section that contains the "
Hixie: Probably not, given the variety of existing web content.
webben: well there's only one section that could possibly be the most relevant one to the image, and that's the header of hte section the image is in
Hixie: Which won't be using HTML5 header semantics.
webben: ?
Hixie: With real-world content that's dubious. But in any case being relevant to the header is not the same thing as the header titling the image.

2. The case where the image isn't the primary content of the section, but just a small part of it. e.g.

Foo

some paragraphs...

something about this image

more paragraphs
Hixie: Existing content won't be using HTML5 header semantics.
Lachy: when would that image ever legitimately not have alt text?
in that case, the image should have an alt="whatever" because it's a key part of the content. But there's no way to distinguish that from case #1
webben: why not?
Lachy: oh well sure, we can't distinguish bogus alt="" text from correct alt="" text either
Lachy: we're talking about what's conforming here
Hixie: Because HTML5 clarifies and reinvents HTML4's ambiguous header semantics, which were close to dead-letter in the real world.
yeah, but the conformance rules you gave above are ambiguous about it
Lachy: do you mean doc conformance or ua confomance?
doc conformance
webben: so? the html5 rules are based on what pages do
Lachy: i don't understand what's ambiguous
Hixie: yes but the conformance rules need to encourage content that AT can actually use, which means helping it distinguish between different scenarios.
webben: we can never help ATs distinguish between correct and incorrect cases
of course you can.
webben: there are plenty of images with wrong alt="" text
yes, that's a particular case you'd struggle to help with
in this case, one clearly could help
webben: there are no cases where authors wouldn't mis-use whatever indicator of conformance we came up with
er ... obviously.
well then
authors will make mistakes. with everything. and the spec can't help.

Hixie, because your proposed conformance rules stated: "we just say that if an image has no alt text, then it must have [a] heading of the section that contains the ". Both cases #1 and #2 I gave fit that condition, even though #2 isn't supposed to be a legitimate case.
guess we don't need a spec?
webben: ??
Hixie: Saying including a feature because some authors will misuse it doesn't make any sense to me.
Lachy: the actual rule would say that the heading has to be the caption of the image or some such
ok, that makes it less ambiguous
Hixie: You'd need to make a case that it would be misused in enough high-profile cases that a UA would be forced to ignore the feature.
webben: you are saying that we shouldn't do what i proposed because pages that aren't conforming would fail on this case, right? but isn't that always goign to be the case?
Hixie: Not sure that is what I'm saying.
webben: what are you saying then?
Hixie: I'm saying that additional markup would help UAs differentiate between a (assumed) common class of non-conformance and a (my guess) rarer class of non-conformance.
hmm or rather class of conformance
that is distinguish between image amongst other content which is not labelled by the heading but is missing alt (common failure)
and image amongst other content which is labelled by the heading and is missing alt (this would be easy for Flickr to implement, for example)
of course, authors might misuse _all_ the features involved.
seems to me that you would be be obtaining this distinction only by increasing the number of cases that were non-conforming in other ways
e.g. with alt and said to be described by somehting else, or said to be described by something that isn't there, etc
said to be described by something that it isn't described by
I think only the last one is a substantial problem.
the middle case can be trivially caught in validation
and in practice I think the last one isn't going to have a big impact
again, this is markup that's trivial for Flickr to implement
i also don't want to introduce an attribute for this one case, and i don't want to rely on aria at this point
and that's the big use case here.
Hixie: I think trying to solve these problems without features is ambitious.
i'd rather not solve the problem at all than introduce a new attribute
attributes are expensive and this is not a case important enough to warrant that level of investment
Yes, that's not a position that makes sense to me.
In practice, UAs/AT have to try and solve these problems whether there are features for them or not.

anyway, even in the case of incorrectly-non-alt'ed images that have no title=, reading the local section title when the user navigates by image to that image isn't a big deal, it still orients the user
and that leads to non-interoperability
and we can say that there must only be one such img in that section, to catch errors of that nature
Hixie: it only orients the user if you say something like "in section {Section title}"
otherwise it misleads the user
right
it also sucks for extraction, since you can't easily map the section title into metadata about the image.
whereas if you knew that something was intended as a title field, you could dump it into a title field
that's not a use case i've previously been worrying about
doesn't seem like something users are going to need particularly
i mean, when i see someone save an image, they don't save any metadata with it today
why would they start?
Hixie: I give what I save titles.
it would be a nice-to-have if it were prepopulated with a sane title.

My Cat

, what should a screen reader say?
whether in the filename or other metadata that could be found by beagle/spotlight etc.

hsivonen: if there is no useful data to give, there is no useful data to give.

webben, if a transcript is not available to a user who would like one, their dissapointment is with the lack of facilities provided by the author rather than the lack of facilities provided by the format

BenMillard: What I've seen is screen reader users, at least, explicitly requesting the ability to jump between different sorts of objects _and_ the ability to jump to content _and_ the ability to read from here.
BenMillard: Yes. But the format is forcing them to search for it.

sod inspecting each one individually :)

webben, you may be overthinking the problem...equally I may be underthinking it. either way, the amount of web content I've studied shows re-using simple structures in simple ways (like an <a href> near to where you need it) is more reliably authored (and therefore more robust) than specialist facilities in the language to do nearly the same thing
I'm not sure I care about it being reliably authored. I'd want to see that markup in major sources of videos.
That is to say, if it makes YouTube better that's a huge win.
if a feature is not reliably authored, nobody wins because it won't work
so I put a higher value on reliability, but that might just be me
it not working on Joe Blogg's site is a lot less important than it working on YouTube.
I suspect Google's engineers are capable of generating such markup (indeed, vastly more complicated markup, if they wanted to).
in contrast, a simpler feature which works everywhere provides a more stable experience for users (even if it takes one extra key press and half a second more aural output each time)
webben, ultimately it's Hixie who decides where the balance is, I suppose :)
I'd certainly agree that simple features are better. However, having explicit markup to associate with transcripts can be an enhancement to the simpler markup.
it's not an either/or situation
it's a bit like microformats being built on top of simpler structures.

indeed. but if the simple feature is adequate for user needs (which would take user testing to establish one way or another, I imagine) then the explicit markup is just a side-show; complicating the authoring process and adding one more way for things to go wrong
for example, consider automatic association of <th> and <td> versus <td headers> for every data cell and <th id> for every header cell
BenMillard: I think I'd agree depending on what adequate means.
I'd prefer people to have a good web experience rather than a merely adequate one.
I'd define "adequate" as something like "task can be completed by users in a timely manner"
webben, but I expect the user testing people have a better idea of it that I
that sounds reasonable
it's the timeliness we have differing suspicions about in this case.
indeed :)
